review_title: Alot of hats rolled into one job
job_title: Care Supervisor in San Francisco, CA

cons: Emotionally draining sometimes, providers sometimes not trained to deal with pressures of job and it is up to supervisors to give training on harder subjects that Provider might not have been prepared for.

review_title: Open to new ideas, tough work, good community
job_title: Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
The directors and chiefs are really open to new ideas.  It feels like anyone who has a new idea has the right to bring it up - it is a very open environment.

Also, there is great teamwork and community. The office staff really collaborate. There's super hard days, of course, but it really feels like people have each other's back. Also, I have seen lots of people get promoted which is awesome.
cons:
The work is really hard. The clients are tough clients, the places we serve are often dirty. It's a nonprofit, so we have to make the most impact with limited resources. Some months there is a lot to do and not enough time. It is hard to get everything done and keep all the pieces in play to make sure the program works at optimum level. 
The home care providers are out in the field working hard, and sometimes  It can be really rewarding, but it can also be so hard to do and feel isolating.
THough I have seen a lot of promotions, there is room to make the career ladder better, and provide more support to people who want to develop.

review_title: Friendly, supportive office environment. Opportunities to move laterally but could do better with internal promotions.
job_title: Service Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Understanding of work/life conflicts (child care, therapy, etc)
Management is supportive, wants to help not penalize
Autonomy in day-to-day job functions (no micromanaging)
Good benefits for individuals (403b retirement, health, dental and vision after 90 days)
Interested in career development goals of employees
cons:
Case loads are either high volume or high intensity, which can be stressful in first 6 months (gets easier over time)
Clients frequently complain about service, mostly due to inexperienced direct service employees (home care aids) who have high turnover rates
Turnover in coworkers and supervisors can lead to extra work while positions remain vacant
Costly to add dependents, partners to health insurance plan (my wife opted for Obamacare instead)

job_title: Outreach Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Stress free work environment; management does not micro manage; workforce development; always above minimum wage; assistance with life problems outside of work; helping someone who is elderly or disabled continue to live independently; great work life balance; awareness of self care importance.
cons: I have worked 3 jobs for a total of 8 years and will not work under a "for profit" company again. Homebridge does not equate your value to the company based on how much of a financial impact you've made. All my work done here will translate to how much of a difference I have made to our clients. Did I connect with a caregiver who went above and beyond while working with clients is my goal to beat everyday- I have zeros cons.

review_title: Good work, lots of turnover in admin
job_title: Home Health Caregiver in San Mateo, CA
pros: The job allowed me to get direct patient care experience which was critical for my nursing application. I was able to work with a wonderfully diverse set of clients, whose lives and stories I carried with me into my nursing classes.
cons: As is typical for this type of work, unfortunately the pay is low. Also, while I was there, there was a ridiculous amount of turnover among the management team.

review_title: WORST PAYROLL METHOD OF ALL TIME!!
job_title: Caregiver in San Francisco, CA
pros: The pros of being a "caregiver",  first and foremost is the wonderful feeling you receive knowing you've helped someone in need. The other advantages include the potential of establishing life-long friendships with the people you help. The flexibility in one's work hours is also a wonderful perk! Between the recipient and provider, the work shifts can be easily established to work advantageously for both. Good medical and dental benefits are also offered.
cons: The biggest "con" to this job is the payroll method. It is by far the most RIDICULOUS and frustrating payroll method I have ever encountered! It is so archaic. Whoever presented the method to the IHSS Consortium should be fired! First, they require a manual submission of one's time sheet every 2 weeks that needs to be "mailed" all the up to Chico, CA, which takes about 2 to 3 days. Then the worst part, the "processing"  Timesheets are processed by a crew of employees that claim they process them in a timely manner. Please note the words, "they" and "claim". I would not use "timely" to describe the duration of their process. After the processing, the check gets cut, placed back into the Pony Express and you wait another 2 to 3 days to get it. All in all, you receive your checks a week (I've waited up to 2 weeks!) to get your check in hand. Most companies are very diligent about making sure their employees are paid on a specific date, not here. You get paid whenever you do. There's no guarantee, so financial budgeting is not an option. Direct Deposit is offered, but after you submit the request, it will take a little over a month to get it enacted. As with everything regarding the payroll method, why the delay? Your guess is as good as mine. lol. I don't understand why this agency doesn't modernize and set up an ONLINE payroll system? It would be 100% more time efficient, "eco-friendly" in doing away with the paper timesheets (as well as the Pony Express!) and cost-effective. Why outsource a crew all the up in Chico, CA.? My only complaint. "That's my story, and I'm sticking to it!"

job_title: Caregiver in San Francisco, CA
pros: Helping Clients  in every way
cons: Disorganized  not a very fit organizatio. Pay rate to low

job_title: Critical Care Case Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Case managers & service coordinators are excellent and really try to do their best with what they have.
cons: Extremely high turnover, providers work with clients in critical need and they are highly un-trained and unskilled to do the tasks they are asked to do which is a huge liability to them, the city, and the organization.  Management at the highest level does not understand the dangers clients are put in by allowing unskilled workers in clients homes.

job_title: Home Health Aide in San Francisco, CA
pros: Highest pay for Home Care Providers in the Bay Area
cons: Where should I begin??.. The training program is too long, boring, and the rules are ridiculous!! If you are late (even by 5-10 minutes) , miss a day, leave (even 5-10 minutes) early then they kick you out of the current training course and then you have to start the 2 week course completely over again! Even if you were on your last day of training, and let's say that you have an emergency, are I'll, etc. they have 0 empathy and will make you start all over again! They are extremely nice when you get hired and during training (sometimes) but once you actually start in the field, you are on your own! They DO NOT care about their employees NOR the clients! There is so much FAVORITISM that it's crazy!! You HAVE TO ONLY take Muni even if you have a car, and if you don't, then you will be fired on the spot! And if your supervisor doesn't really care for you, they will assign you cases that are on opposite sides of the city! I spent a majority of my days just traveling to and from my clients (and you DO NOT get paid for travel, even though they say you will)! Also be sure to keep very clear and concise records of the time/s you work including time, location, travel time/distance, client identity and have your client sign every single time that you are there, because Homebridge WILL try and short your pay!
